heading: Chronic Headaches
text: Both migraines and tension-type headaches can become chronic, meaning that they occur at least 15 days per month for greater than 3 months  Chronic headaches can result from taking some types of medication—for example, acetaminophen (Tylenol), ibuprofen (Motrin), caffeine, and some prescription medications—almost every day. These are called medication overuse headaches. The most effective way to make these headaches better is to stop taking pain medicines altogether for 2 to 3 weeks. After that time, use of pain-relievers is limited to no more that 2 to 3 times per week.

heading: CN III Palsy — Surgical vs Medical
text:
"Surgical" (pupil-involving): Mydriasis + ptosis + limited adduction/elevation/depression → concern for posterior communicating artery (PComm) aneurysm compression. Urgent CTA/MRA.
"Medical" (pupil-sparing): Ptosis + eye movement limitation but normal pupil → microvascular (diabetes, hypertension). More common in adults; rare in children.
In children: Pupil-sparing distinction is less reliable. Any CN III palsy in a child warrants imaging.

heading: VPA-Induced Hyperammonemic Encephalopathy
text: Can occur even with therapeutic VPA levels. Suspect in any patient on VPA with acute confusion, lethargy, vomiting, or worsening seizures.

heading: Recognition
text:
Check ammonia level in any encephalopathic patient on valproic acid — even if VPA level is "therapeutic."

Ammonia > 80 µmol/L — clinically significant
Ammonia > 100 µmol/L — concerning, likely symptomatic
Ammonia > 200 µmol/L — critical, risk of cerebral edema

Also check: hepatic function panel (AST, ALT, total/direct bilirubin), VPA level, CBC with platelets, lipase

heading: VPA Overdose
text:
VPA level > 150 mg/L: Significant toxicity likely — L-carnitine, supportive care
VPA level > 300 mg/L: Severe — consider hemodialysis (VPA is protein-bound at therapeutic levels but saturation occurs at high concentrations, making dialysis more effective)

heading: If Seizure Suspected — Initial Workup
text:
Stat labs: Glucose, BMP (calcium, magnesium, sodium), blood gas, lactate
Infection workup: CBC, blood culture, consider LP (CSF studies + HSV PCR)
EEG: Continuous video EEG monitoring if seizure confirmed or ongoing suspicion
Imaging: Head ultrasound (bedside), MRI brain when stable
Consider: Urine organic acids, serum amino acids, ammonia if metabolic etiology suspected
First-line treatment: Phenobarbital 20 mg/kg IV loading dose

heading: Step 1: Immediate Measures
text:
Notify neurosurgery — NSGY typically aids in ICP management
Optimize sedation and pain control
Head of bed elevated to 30°, head and neck midline (optimize venous drainage)
Hyperventilate to PaCO₂ 32-35 mmHg (temporary bridge only — do not maintain)
If EVD/ICP drain present: unclamp, set at 15 mmHg, notify NSGY
See Pupillometry section for noninvasive ICP trending (NPI < 3 = pathological)

heading: Step 2: First-Line — Hypertonic Saline
text:
3% Hypertonic Saline (HTS) — 0.5 mEq/mL Na⁺

Dose: 5 mL/kg IV bolus via peripheral IV or central line
May repeat if ICP remains elevated
Hold if serum Na⁺ ≥ 165 mmol/L
Monitor serum sodium every 4-6 hours

heading: Step 3: Second-Line — Mannitol
text:
Use if fluid overloaded or not responsive to HTS:

Dose: Mannitol 0.5-1 g/kg IV bolus
Hold if serum osmolarity ≥ 340 mOsm/kg
May repeat after 15 minutes if ICP remains elevated
Monitor serum osmolarity, electrolytes, and volume status

heading: Step 4: Refractory ICP
text:
If ICP remains elevated despite Steps 1-3:

Neuromuscular blockade (eliminates shivering, coughing, ventilator dyssynchrony)
Deep sedation:
  
  Ketamine + midazolam infusion, OR
  Pentobarbital coma — titrate to burst suppression on cEEG
  

Therapeutic hypothermia to 32-34°C
Neurosurgical intervention: decompressive craniectomy, hemicraniectomy
